content.description:
Shares a start with God of Fire. Climb the corner up onto the face, passing a bolt and two pins. Cut left after the face section and head toward a bolt.

Anchors are to the left under the prow about 2/3rds of the way up the wall.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 pins, light rack. Bolted anchors.

climbs.name: Triple Treat
climbs.fa: Tom Howard, Nick Brash and Doug Reed

content.description: Jamming-intensive climbing through a corner system and over three roofs. So good!
content.location: Middle route of Orchard Wall. Under triple roofs.

content.description:
You get exactly what you pay for, you paid for the full package and by Joe you shall receive it! There is a crux from 1st to third bolt, save some energy for the moves up the arete, some hold finding may need be done as a bit of the upper portion is lichen covered. You will want a long sling on bolt 6.

WATCH AT THE ANCHOR FOR BEES.
content.protection: 7 bolts to ring bolt anchors. Rappelling down is advisable.
content.location: The route starts behind some pine trees and hemlocks. The route is the obvious blunt arete with crisp crimps.

content.description: Sequential finger tips climbing off the ground leads to a larger hand crack and stances.  Follow plumb line to the anchors found to the left of the crack.
content.protection: Everything from .4 to #4. Nuts. Bolted anchor.

content.description: Start on a hand crack and move into long moves to jugs.  Mid route, navigate a wide section, then finish by utilizing horizontal holds and any kind of finger jamming you can manage.  This is a short route, but every bit as classic as the surrounding lines at Orchard.
content.protection: This route will take everything from 6 to .4.  However, with good management, you could probably get away with 4 - .4.  Doubles in the .75 - .4 range will give you lots of options.  2 bolt anchor with rings to the left of the crack at the top.
content.location: The wide crack just left of Hysteria.

content.description:
Ultra classic hard trad route!

Short handcrack splitter to some juggy steep stuff, and then a steeper thin hands and finger crack in a corner.  Stemming will help you save juice for later; you'll need it!  There is a fixed piece at the top of this dihedral.  From here, hand traverse out a very airy ledge to an awkward heel-toe stance below the final headwall.  Set a bomber piece (or two), and pray that your v-bouldering skills are up to par for the crux headwall's amazing combination of tips locks and sidepull slaps.  Two-bolt anchor.
content.protection: hands to tiny.  Extra red camalots worked very well for me throughout this climb.  Option of a wide piece (#4) in the horizontal at the roof.  Bolted anchor.
content.location: One of the first routes you walk under approaching the Orchard Wall from downstream end.

content.description: This short route packs quite a punch.  A couple moves off the ground gets you to a stance under the roof.  A hard pull off the stance will take you through decent holds, pumpy, painful jams, and tricky footwork. The crux is pulling the flare at the lip!
content.protection: Single rack from .3 Camalot to 4. As of this post date, there is a two-nut anchor (I added one) with a single oval biner, and also a fixed #1 Camalot at the lip.
content.location: Far right end of Orchard wall is where you'll find this 20' roof crack.

content.description:
(Note: I've not done this underloved line, but have added it since it recently got new top anchors added. -pnelson)

This is the obvious crack a few dozen feet to the left of Shiny Faces. It's short, steep, and flared, and looks pretty legit for the grade. Get on it!
content.protection: Finger-sized gear, new bolted top anchor.
content.location: Left of Shiny Faces, and the first crack on the buttress facing Springboard from across the small alcove.

content.description: Begin ~15 feet right of Springboard in a licheny crack. Climb fun crack up to a leftwards face traverse and finish up a small right facing corner to the Springboard anchors.

Round the corner to climber's right of Shiny Faces for the start to this route- immediately to the right of a roof/overhang.  Look for a fairly sheer face with horizontals that's quite Gunks-esque.  The hardest moves are right off the ground.  Follow the horizontals for about 35-40 feet until you reach a comfy ledge.  This ends the 5.8 climbing.  From here, choose your own adventure for roughly 5.5 climbing for the second half of the route until you reach the bolted anchor and a gorgeous view.
content.protection: This takes all kinds of gear. Tri-cams are helpful for the many horizontals, but small cams work well too.  It'll take anything from .1 to .5 but definitely more on the small end.  The upper part takes just about anything you have on you.  There are a few holds that can be slung as well.   Bolted anchor.
content.location: Continue upstream from Orchard wall proper. You will see the Shiny Faces offwidth/roof just before you reach Hysteria.

content.description:
Shares a start with White-Out. Climb the corner up onto the face, passing a bolt and two pins. Cut right after the face section and head toward a bolt.

Anchors are to the left under the prow about 2/3rds of the way up the wall.
content.protection: 2 bolts, 2 pins, light rack. Bolted anchors.

content.description: I'm sure that it's been done by plenty of folks over the decades, but the slab between Bisect and Anal Clenching Adventures goes, and with some very engaging slab moves.
content.protection: The shared anchors for the two 5.10 cracks. You could lead this gritstone-style with a gear nest halfway up, but there would be ankle breaking potential for sure at the crux.
content.location: Obvious face between the two 5.10 cracks, Bisect and Anal Clenching Adventures.

content.description: Start in a dihedral below a roof. Pull the low roof to slabby crack. If you can pull the low crux just above the roof, you'll easily pull the rest. Soloed by Doug Reed for the first ascent.
content.protection: Nothing bigger than #2.  Multiples of .3, .4 and .5 are nice, but not necessary.  Shared bolted anchor with Anal Clenching Adventures.
content.location: Located to the left of Anal Clenching Adventures.

climbs.name: Anal Clenching Adventures
climbs.fa: Rick Skidmore, Hobart Parks, Steve Erskine 1979  FFA Mike Artz free solo

content.description: A short crack that requires some slabby smears as well as tenuous jams where the crack flares out.
content.protection:
Everything from 3 to 00.

Bolts and rings at the top- shared with Bisect.
content.location: Just to the left of Triple Treat and Springboard.
